meta.brief: Git blob load and write routines
meta.defgroup: git_blob Git blob load and write routines
git_commit Git commit parsing, formatting routines

meta.brief: Git error handling routines and variables
Git index parsing and manipulation routines
meta.defgroup: git_index Git index parsing and manipulation routines
git_object Git revision object management routines
git_tree Git tree parsing, loading routines

git_attr_get.argline:
git_repository *repo, const char *path, const char *name,
	const char **value
git_attr_get.description: Lookup attribute for path returning string caller must free

git_attr_get_many.argline:
git_repository *repo, const char *path,
    size_t num_attr, const char **names,
	const char **values
git_attr_get_many.description: Lookup list of attributes for path, populating array of strings

git_attr_foreach.argline:
git_repository *repo, const char *path,
	int (*callback)(const char *name, const char *value, void *payload),
	void *payload
git_attr_foreach.sig: git_repository *::const char *::int (*)(const char *name, const char *value, void *payload)::void *
git_attr_foreach.description: Perform an operation on each attribute of a path.

git_attr_cache_flush.comments: Call this if you have reason to believe that the attributes files on disk no longer match the cached contents of memory.

git_attr_add_macro.comments:
Macros will automatically be loaded from the top level .gitattributes file of the repository (plus the build-in "binary" macro). This function allows you to add others. For example, to add the default macro, you would call:

git_attr_add_macro(repo, "binary", "-diff -crlf");

args.name: blob
args.comment: pointer to the looked up blob

args.name: repo
args.comment: the repo to use when locating the blob.

args.name: id
args.comment: identity of the blob to locate.

git_blob_lookup.description: Lookup a blob object from a repository.

args.name: blob
args.comment: pointer to the looked up blob

args.name: repo
args.comment: the repo to use when locating the blob.

args.name: id
args.comment: identity of the blob to locate.

args.name: len
args.comment: the length of the short identifier

git_blob_lookup_prefix.argline: git_blob **blob, git_repository *repo, const git_oid *id, unsigned int len
git_blob_lookup_prefix.description: Lookup a blob object from a repository, given a prefix of its identifier (short id).

git_blob_free.comments:
This is a wrapper around git_object_free()

IMPORTANT: It is necessary to call this method when you stop using a blob. Failure to do so will cause a memory leak.

return.comment: the pointer; NULL if the blob has no contents

git_blob_rawcontent.description: Get a read-only buffer with the raw content of a blob.
git_blob_rawcontent.comments: A pointer to the raw content of a blob is returned; this pointer is owned internally by the object and shall not be free'd. The pointer may be invalidated at a later time.

git_blob_rawsize.description: Get the size in bytes of the contents of a blob

args.name: oid
args.comment: return the id of the written blob

args.name: repo
args.comment: repository where the blob will be written. this repository cannot be bare

args.name: path
args.comment: file from which the blob will be created, relative to the repository's working dir

git_blob_create_fromfile.description: Read a file from the working folder of a repository and write it to the Object Database as a loose blob

args.name: oid
args.comment: return the oid of the written blob

args.name: repo
args.comment: repository where to blob will be written

args.name: buffer
args.comment: data to be written into the blob

git_blob_create_frombuffer.argline: git_oid *oid, git_repository *repo, const void *buffer, size_t len
git_blob_create_frombuffer.description: Write an in-memory buffer to the ODB as a blob

args.name: commit
args.comment: pointer to the looked up commit

args.name: repo
args.comment: the repo to use when locating the commit.

args.name: id
args.comment: identity of the commit to locate. If the object is an annotated tag it will be peeled back to the commit.

git_commit_lookup.description: Lookup a commit object from a repository.

args.name: commit
args.comment: pointer to the looked up commit

args.name: repo
args.comment: the repo to use when locating the commit.

args.name: id
args.comment: identity of the commit to locate. If the object is an annotated tag it will be peeled back to the commit.

args.name: len
args.comment: the length of the short identifier

git_commit_lookup_prefix.argline: git_commit **commit, git_repository *repo, const git_oid *id, unsigned len
git_commit_lookup_prefix.description: Lookup a commit object from a repository, given a prefix of its identifier (short id).

git_commit_free.comments:
This is a wrapper around git_object_free()

IMPORTANT: It is necessary to call this method when you stop using a commit. Failure to do so will cause a memory leak.

git_commit_message_encoding.description: Get the encoding for the message of a commit, as a string representing a standard encoding name.
git_commit_message_encoding.comments: The encoding may be NULL if the encoding header in the commit is missing; in that case UTF-8 is assumed.

git_commit_message.description: Get the full message of a commit.

git_commit_time.description: Get the commit time (i.e. committer time) of a commit.

return.comment: positive or negative timezone offset, in minutes from UTC

git_commit_time_offset.description: Get the commit timezone offset (i.e. committer's preferred timezone) of a commit.

args.name: tree_out
args.comment: pointer where to store the tree object

git_commit_tree.description: Get the tree pointed to by a commit.

return.comment: the id of tree pointed to by commit.

git_commit_tree_oid.description: Get the id of the tree pointed to by a commit. This differs from git_commit_tree in that no attempts are made to fetch an object from the ODB.

git_commit_parentcount.description: Get the number of parents of this commit

args.name: parent
args.comment: Pointer where to store the parent commit

args.name: n
args.comment: the position of the parent (from 0 to `parentcount`)

git_commit_parent.description: Get the specified parent of the commit.

args.name: n
args.comment: the position of the parent (from 0 to `parentcount`)

return.comment: the id of the parent, NULL on error.

git_commit_parent_oid.description: Get the oid of a specified parent for a commit. This is different from git_commit_parent, which will attempt to load the parent commit from the ODB.

args.name: oid
args.comment: Pointer where to store the OID of the newly created commit

args.name: repo
args.comment: Repository where to store the commit

args.name: update_ref
args.comment: If not NULL, name of the reference that will be updated to point to this commit. If the reference is not direct, it will be resolved to a direct reference. Use "HEAD" to update the HEAD of the current branch and make it point to this commit

args.name: author
args.comment: Signature representing the author and the authory time of this commit

args.name: committer
args.comment: Signature representing the committer and the commit time of this commit

args.name: message_encoding
args.comment: The encoding for the message in the commit, represented with a standard encoding name. E.g. "UTF-8". If NULL, no encoding header is written and UTF-8 is assumed.

args.name: message
args.comment: _encoding The encoding for the message in the commit, represented with a standard encoding name. E.g. "UTF-8". If NULL, no encoding header is written and UTF-8 is assumed.

args.name: tree
args.comment: An instance of a `git_tree` object that will be used as the tree for the commit. This tree object must also be owned by the given `repo`.

args.name: parent_count
args.comment: Number of parents for this commit

git_commit_create.sig: git_oid *::git_repository *::const char *::const git_signature *::const git_signature *::const char *::const char *::const git_tree *::int

return.comment: GIT_SUCCESS or an error code The created commit will be written to the Object Database and the given reference will be updated to point to it

git_commit_create.description: Create a new commit in the repository using git_object instances as parameters.

git_commit_create_v.sig: git_oid *::git_repository *::const char *::const git_signature *::const git_signature *::const char *::const char *::const git_tree *::int
git_commit_create_v.description: Create a new commit in the repository using a variable argument list.
git_commit_create_v.comments:
The parents for the commit are specified as a variable list of pointers to const git_commit *. Note that this is a convenience method which may not be safe to export for certain languages or compilers

All other parameters remain the same

@see git_commit_create

git_libgit2_version.description: Return the version of the libgit2 library being currently used.

args.name: global_config_path
args.comment: Buffer of GIT_PATH_MAX length to store the path

return.comment: GIT_SUCCESS if a global configuration file has been found. Its path will be stored in `buffer`.

git_config_find_global.description: Locate the path to the global configuration file
git_config_find_global.comments:
The user or global configuration file is usually located in $HOME/.gitconfig.

This method will try to guess the full path to that file, if the file exists. The returned path may be used on any git_config call to load the global configuration file.

args.name: system_config_path
args.comment: Buffer of GIT_PATH_MAX length to store the path

return.comment: GIT_SUCCESS if a system configuration file has been found. Its path will be stored in `buffer`.

git_config_find_system.description: Locate the path to the system configuration file
git_config_find_system.comments: If /etc/gitconfig doesn't exist, it will look for %PROGRAMFILES%\Git\etc\gitconfig.

args.name: out
args.comment: Pointer to store the config instance

git_config_open_global.comments: Utility wrapper that calls git_config_find_global and opens the located file, if it exists.

args.name: path
args.comment: where the config file is located

git_config_file__ondisk.description: Create a configuration file backend for ondisk files
git_config_file__ondisk.comments: These are the normal .gitconfig files that Core Git processes. Note that you first have to add this file to a configuration object before you can query it for configuration variables.

git_config_new.comments: This object is empty, so you have to add a file to it before you can do anything with it.

args.name: cfg
args.comment: the configuration to add the file to

args.name: priority
args.comment: the priority the backend should have

git_config_add_file.description: Add a generic config file instance to an existing config
git_config_add_file.comments:
Note that the configuration object will free the file automatically.

Further queries on this config object will access each of the config file instances in order (instances with a higher priority will be accessed first).

args.name: cfg
args.comment: the configuration to add the file to

args.name: path
args.comment: path to the configuration file (backend) to add

args.name: priority
args.comment: the priority the backend should have

git_config_add_file_ondisk.description: Add an on-disk config file instance to an existing config
git_config_add_file_ondisk.comments:
The on-disk file pointed at by path will be opened and parsed; it's expected to be a native Git config file following the default Git config syntax (see man git-config).

Note that the configuration object will free the file automatically.

Further queries on this config object will access each of the config file instances in order (instances with a higher priority will be accessed first).

args.name: path
args.comment: Path to the on-disk file to open

git_config_open_ondisk.description: Create a new config instance containing a single on-disk file
git_config_open_ondisk.comments: This method is a simple utility wrapper for the following sequence of calls: - git_config_new - git_config_add_file_ondisk

git_config_free.description: Free the configuration and its associated memory and files

args.name: cfg
args.comment: where to look for the variable

args.name: out
args.comment: pointer to the variable where the value should be stored

git_config_get_int32.description: Get the value of an integer config variable.

args.name: cfg
args.comment: where to look for the variable

args.name: out
args.comment: pointer to the variable where the value should be stored

git_config_get_int64.description: Get the value of a long integer config variable.

args.name: cfg
args.comment: where to look for the variable

args.name: out
args.comment: pointer to the variable where the value should be stored

git_config_get_bool.description: Get the value of a boolean config variable.
git_config_get_bool.comments: This function uses the usual C convention of 0 being false and anything else true.

args.name: cfg
args.comment: where to look for the variable

git_config_get_string.description: Get the value of a string config variable.
git_config_get_string.comments: The string is owned by the variable and should not be freed by the user.

args.name: cfg
args.comment: where to look for the variable

git_config_set_int32.description: Set the value of an integer config variable.

args.name: cfg
args.comment: where to look for the variable

args.name: value
args.comment: Long integer value for the variable

git_config_set_int64.description: Set the value of a long integer config variable.

args.name: cfg
args.comment: where to look for the variable

git_config_set_bool.description: Set the value of a boolean config variable.

args.name: cfg
args.comment: where to look for the variable

git_config_set_string.description: Set the value of a string config variable.
git_config_set_string.comments: A copy of the string is made and the user is free to use it afterwards.

args.name: cfg
args.comment: where to get the variables from

args.name: callback
args.comment: the function to call on each variable

args.name: payload
args.comment: the data to pass to the callback

git_config_foreach.argline:
git_config *cfg,
	int (*callback)(const char *var_name, const char *value, void *payload),
	void *payload

return.comment: GIT_SUCCESS or the return value of the callback which didn't return 0

git_config_foreach.description: Perform an operation on each config variable.
git_config_foreach.comments: The callback receives the normalized name and value of each variable in the config backend, and the data pointer passed to this function. As soon as one of the callback functions returns something other than 0, this function returns that value.

git_lasterror.description: Return a detailed error string with the latest error that occurred in the library. @return a string explaining the error

return.comment: a string explaining the error code

git_strerror.comments: Get a string description for a given error code. NOTE: This method will be eventually deprecated in favor of the new git_lasterror.

args.name: index
args.comment: the pointer for the new index

args.name: index_path
args.comment: the path to the index file in disk

git_index_open.description: Create a new bare Git index object as a memory representation of the Git index file in 'index_path', without a repository to back it.
git_index_open.comments:
Since there is no ODB or working directory behind this index, any Index methods which rely on these (e.g. index_add) will fail with the GIT_EBAREINDEX error code.

If you need to access the index of an actual repository, use the git_repository_index wrapper.

The index must be freed once it's no longer in use.

git_index_clear.description: Clear the contents (all the entries) of an index object. This clears the index object in memory; changes must be manually written to disk for them to take effect.

git_index_read.description: Update the contents of an existing index object in memory by reading from the hard disk.

git_index_write.description: Write an existing index object from memory back to disk using an atomic file lock.

git_index_find.description: Find the first index of any entries which point to given path in the Git index.

git_index_uniq.description: Remove all entries with equal path except last added

git_index_add.description: Add or update an index entry from a file in disk
git_index_add.comments:
The file path must be relative to the repository's working folder and must be readable.

This method will fail in bare index instances.

This forces the file to be added to the index, not looking at gitignore rules. Those rules can be evaluated through the git_status APIs (in status.h) before calling this.

git_index_add2.description: Add or update an index entry from an in-memory struct
git_index_add2.comments: A full copy (including the 'path' string) of the given 'source_entry' will be inserted on the index.

git_index_append.description: Add (append) an index entry from a file in disk
git_index_append.comments:
A new entry will always be inserted into the index; if the index already contains an entry for such path, the old entry will not be replaced.

The file path must be relative to the repository's working folder and must be readable.

This method will fail in bare index instances.

git_index_append2.description: Add (append) an index entry from an in-memory struct
git_index_append2.comments:
A new entry will always be inserted into the index; if the index already contains an entry for the path in the entry struct, the old entry will not be replaced.

A full copy (including the 'path' string) of the given 'source_entry' will be inserted on the index.

args.name: position
args.comment: position of the entry to remove

return.comment: a pointer to the entry; NULL if out of bounds

git_index_get.description: Get a pointer to one of the entries in the index
git_index_get.comments:
This entry can be modified, and the changes will be written back to disk on the next write() call.

The entry should not be freed by the caller.

return.comment: integer of count of current entries

git_index_entrycount.description: Get the count of entries currently in the index

return.comment: integer of count of current unmerged entries

git_index_entrycount_unmerged.description: Get the count of unmerged entries currently in the index

return.comment: the unmerged entry; NULL if not found

git_index_get_unmerged_bypath.description: Get an unmerged entry from the index.
git_index_get_unmerged_bypath.comments: The returned entry is read-only and should not be modified of freed by the caller.

return.comment: a pointer to the unmerged entry; NULL if out of bounds

git_index_get_unmerged_byindex.description: Get an unmerged entry from the index.
git_index_get_unmerged_byindex.comments: The returned entry is read-only and should not be modified of freed by the caller.

git_index_entry_stage.description: Return the stage number from a git index entry
git_index_entry_stage.comments:
This entry is calculated from the entrie's flag attribute like this:

(entry->flags & GIT_IDXENTRY_STAGEMASK) >> GIT_IDXENTRY_STAGESHIFT

git_index_read_tree.description: Read a tree into the index file
git_index_read_tree.comments: The current index contents will be replaced by the specified tree.

args.name: out
args.comment: where to store the indexer instance

args.name: packname
args.comment: the absolute filename of the packfile to index

git_indexer_run.description: Iterate over the objects in the packfile and extract the information
git_indexer_run.comments: Indexing a packfile can be very expensive so this function is expected to be run in a worker thread and the stats used to provide feedback the user.

git_indexer_write.comments: The file will be stored as pack-$hash.idx in the same directory as the packfile.

git_indexer_hash.comments: A packfile's name is derived from the sorted hashing of all object names. This is only correct after the index has been written to disk.

args.name: repo
args.comment: the repository to look up the object

args.name: id
args.comment: the unique identifier for the object

git_object_lookup.argline:
git_object **object,
		git_repository *repo,
		const git_oid *id,
		git_otype type
git_object_lookup.description: Lookup a reference to one of the objects in a repostory.
git_object_lookup.comments:
The generated reference is owned by the repository and should be closed with the git_object_free method instead of free'd manually.

The 'type' parameter must match the type of the object in the odb; the method will fail otherwise. The special value 'GIT_OBJ_ANY' may be passed to let the method guess the object's type.

args.name: object_out
args.comment: pointer where to store the looked-up object

args.name: repo
args.comment: the repository to look up the object

args.name: id
args.comment: a short identifier for the object

args.name: len
args.comment: the length of the short identifier

git_object_lookup_prefix.argline:
git_object **object_out,
		git_repository *repo,
		const git_oid *id,
		unsigned int len,
		git_otype type
git_object_lookup_prefix.description: Lookup a reference to one of the objects in a repostory, given a prefix of its identifier (short id).
git_object_lookup_prefix.comments:
The object obtained will be so that its identifier matches the first 'len' hexadecimal characters (packets of 4 bits) of the given 'id'. 'len' must be at least GIT_OID_MINPREFIXLEN, and long enough to identify a unique object matching the prefix; otherwise the method will fail.

The generated reference is owned by the repository and should be closed with the git_object_free method instead of free'd manually.

The 'type' parameter must match the type of the object in the odb; the method will fail otherwise. The special value 'GIT_OBJ_ANY' may be passed to let the method guess the object's type.

git_object_id.description: Get the id (SHA1) of a repository object

git_object_type.description: Get the object type of an object

return.comment: the repository who owns this object

git_object_owner.description: Get the repository that owns this object
git_object_owner.comments:
Freeing or calling git_repository_close on the returned pointer will invalidate the actual object.

Any other operation may be run on the repository without affecting the object.

git_object_free.comments:
This method instructs the library to close an existing object; note that git_objects are owned and cached by the repository so the object may or may not be freed after this library call, depending on how agressive is the caching mechanism used by the repository.

IMPORTANT: It is necessary to call this method when you stop using an object. Failure to do so will cause a memory leak.

git_object_type2string.description: Convert an object type to it's string representation.
git_object_type2string.comments: The result is a pointer to a string in static memory and should not be free()'ed.

git_object_string2type.description: Convert a string object type representation to it's git_otype.

return.comment: true if the type represents a valid loose object type, false otherwise.

git_object_typeisloose.description: Determine if the given git_otype is a valid loose object type.

args.name: type
args.comment: object type to get its size

return.comment: size in bytes of the object

git_object__size.description: Get the size in bytes for the structure which acts as an in-memory representation of any given object type.
git_object__size.comments: For all the core types, this would the equivalent of calling sizeof(git_commit) if the core types were not opaque on the external API.

args.name: out
args.comment: location to store the database pointer, if opened. Set to NULL if the open failed.

git_odb_new.description: Create a new object database with no backends.
git_odb_new.comments: Before the ODB can be used for read/writing, a custom database backend must be manually added using git_odb_add_backend()

args.name: out
args.comment: location to store the database pointer, if opened. Set to NULL if the open failed.

git_odb_open.description: Create a new object database and automatically add the two default backends:
git_odb_open.comments:
• git_odb_backend_loose: read and write loose object files from disk, assuming objects_dir as the Objects folder

  • git_odb_backend_pack: read objects from packfiles, assuming objects_dir as the Objects folder which contains a 'pack/' folder with the corresponding data

args.name: odb
args.comment: database to add the backend to

args.name: priority
args.comment: Value for ordering the backends queue

git_odb_add_backend.description: Add a custom backend to an existing Object DB
git_odb_add_backend.comments:
The backends are checked in relative ordering, based on the value of the priority parameter.

Read for more information.

args.name: odb
args.comment: database to add the backend to

args.name: priority
args.comment: Value for ordering the backends queue

git_odb_add_alternate.description: Add a custom backend to an existing Object DB; this backend will work as an alternate.
git_odb_add_alternate.comments:
Alternate backends are always checked for objects after all the main backends have been exhausted.

The backends are checked in relative ordering, based on the value of the priority parameter.

Writing is disabled on alternate backends.

Read for more information.

args.name: db
args.comment: database pointer to close. If NULL no action is taken.

args.name: out
args.comment: pointer where to store the read object

args.name: db
args.comment: database to search for the object in.

args.name: id
args.comment: identity of the object to read.

return.comment: - GIT_SUCCESS if the object was read; - GIT_ENOTFOUND if the object is not in the database.

git_odb_read.comments:
This method queries all available ODB backends trying to read the given OID.

The returned object is reference counted and internally cached, so it should be closed by the user once it's no longer in use.

args.name: out
args.comment: pointer where to store the read object

args.name: db
args.comment: database to search for the object in.

args.name: short_id
args.comment: a prefix of the id of the object to read.

git_odb_read_prefix.argline: git_odb_object **out, git_odb *db, const git_oid *short_id, unsigned int len

return.comment: GIT_SUCCESS if the object was read; GIT_ENOTFOUND if the object is not in the database. GIT_EAMBIGUOUS if the prefix is ambiguous (several objects match the prefix)

git_odb_read_prefix.description: Read an object from the database, given a prefix of its identifier.
git_odb_read_prefix.comments:
This method queries all available ODB backends trying to match the 'len' first hexadecimal characters of the 'short_id'. The remaining (GIT_OID_HEXSZ-len)*4 bits of 'short_id' must be 0s. 'len' must be at least GIT_OID_MINPREFIXLEN, and the prefix must be long enough to identify a unique object in all the backends; the method will fail otherwise.

The returned object is reference counted and internally cached, so it should be closed by the user once it's no longer in use.

args.name: len_p
args.comment: pointer where to store the length

args.name: type_p
args.comment: pointer where to store the type

args.name: db
args.comment: database to search for the object in.

args.name: id
args.comment: identity of the object to read.

return.comment: - GIT_SUCCESS if the object was read; - GIT_ENOTFOUND if the object is not in the database.

git_odb_read_header.description: Read the header of an object from the database, without reading its full contents.
git_odb_read_header.comments:
The header includes the length and the type of an object.

Note that most backends do not support reading only the header of an object, so the whole object will be read and then the header will be returned.

args.name: db
args.comment: database to be searched for the given object.

return.comment: - 1, if the object was found - 0, otherwise

git_odb_exists.description: Determine if the given object can be found in the object database.

args.name: oid
args.comment: pointer to store the OID result of the write

args.name: odb
args.comment: object database where to store the object

args.name: data
args.comment: buffer with the data to storr

args.name: type
args.comment: type of the data to store

git_odb_write.argline: git_oid *oid, git_odb *odb, const void *data, size_t len, git_otype type
git_odb_write.description: Write an object directly into the ODB
git_odb_write.comments:
This method writes a full object straight into the ODB. For most cases, it is preferred to write objects through a write stream, which is both faster and less memory intensive, specially for big objects.

This method is provided for compatibility with custom backends which are not able to support streaming writes

args.name: stream
args.comment: pointer where to store the stream

args.name: db
args.comment: object database where the stream will write

args.name: size
args.comment: final size of the object that will be written

args.name: type
args.comment: type of the object that will be written

git_odb_open_wstream.argline: git_odb_stream **stream, git_odb *db, size_t size, git_otype type

return.comment: 0 if the stream was created; error code otherwise

git_odb_open_wstream.description: Open a stream to write an object into the ODB
git_odb_open_wstream.comments:
The type and final length of the object must be specified when opening the stream.

The returned stream will be of type GIT_STREAM_WRONLY and will have the following methods:

- stream->write: write `n` bytes into the stream
- stream->finalize_write: close the stream and store the object in
    the odb
- stream->free: free the stream

The streaming write won't be effective until stream->finalize_write is called and returns without an error

The stream must always be free'd or will leak memory.

@see git_odb_stream

args.name: stream
args.comment: pointer where to store the stream

args.name: db
args.comment: object database where the stream will read from

args.name: oid
args.comment: oid of the object the stream will read from

return.comment: 0 if the stream was created; error code otherwise

git_odb_open_rstream.description: Open a stream to read an object from the ODB
git_odb_open_rstream.comments:
Note that most backends do not support streaming reads because they store their objects as compressed/delta'ed blobs.

It's recommended to use git_odb_read instead, which is assured to work on all backends.

The returned stream will be of type GIT_STREAM_RDONLY and will have the following methods:

- stream->read: read `n` bytes from the stream
- stream->free: free the stream

The stream must always be free'd or will leak memory.

@see git_odb_stream

git_odb_hash.argline: git_oid *id, const void *data, size_t len, git_otype type
git_odb_hash.description: Determine the object-ID (sha1 hash) of a data buffer
git_odb_hash.comments: The resulting SHA-1 OID will the itentifier for the data buffer as if the data buffer it were to written to the ODB.

args.name: out
args.comment: oid structure the result is written into.

args.name: path
args.comment: file to read and determine object id for

args.name: type
args.comment: the type of the object that will be hashed

git_odb_hashfile.description: Read a file from disk and fill a git_oid with the object id that the file would have if it were written to the Object Database as an object of the given type. Similar functionality to git.git's git hash-object without the -w flag.

git_odb_object_free.comments: This method must always be called once a git_odb_object is no longer needed, otherwise memory will leak.

git_odb_object_id.description: Return the OID of an ODB object
git_odb_object_id.comments: This is the OID from which the object was read from

git_odb_object_data.description: Return the data of an ODB object
git_odb_object_data.comments:
This is the uncompressed, raw data as read from the ODB, without the leading header.

This pointer is owned by the object and shall not be free'd.

git_odb_object_size.description: Return the size of an ODB object
git_odb_object_size.comments: This is the real size of the data buffer, not the actual size of the object.

git_odb_object_type.description: Return the type of an ODB object

args.name: out
args.comment: oid structure the result is written into.

args.name: str
args.comment: input hex string; must be pointing at the start of the hex sequence and have at least the number of bytes needed for an oid encoded in hex (40 bytes).

git_oid_fromstr.description: Parse a hex formatted object id into a git_oid.

args.name: out
args.comment: oid structure the result is written into.

args.name: str
args.comment: input hex string of at least size `length`

git_oid_fromstrn.description: Parse N characters of a hex formatted object id into a git_oid
git_oid_fromstrn.comments: If N is odd, N-1 characters will be parsed instead. The remaining space in the git_oid will be set to zero.

args.name: out
args.comment: oid structure the result is written into.

args.name: raw
args.comment: the raw input bytes to be copied.

git_oid_fromraw.description: Copy an already raw oid into a git_oid structure.

args.name: str
args.comment: output hex string; must be pointing at the start of the hex sequence and have at least the number of bytes needed for an oid encoded in hex (40 bytes). Only the oid digits are written; a '\\0' terminator must be added by the caller if it is required.

git_oid_fmt.description: Format a git_oid into a hex string.

args.name: str
args.comment: output hex string; must be pointing at the start of the hex sequence and have at least the number of bytes needed for an oid encoded in hex (41 bytes). Only the oid digits are written; a '\\0' terminator must be added by the caller if it is required.

git_oid_pathfmt.description: Format a git_oid into a loose-object path string.
git_oid_pathfmt.comments: The resulting string is "aa/...", where "aa" is the first two hex digitis of the oid and "..." is the remaining 38 digits.

return.comment: the c-string; NULL if memory is exhausted. Caller must deallocate the string with git__free().

git_oid_allocfmt.description: Format a git_oid into a newly allocated c-string.

args.name: out
args.comment: the buffer into which the oid string is output.

args.name: n
args.comment: the size of the out buffer.

return.comment: the out buffer pointer, assuming no input parameter errors, otherwise a pointer to an empty string.

git_oid_to_string.description: Format a git_oid into a buffer as a hex format c-string.
git_oid_to_string.comments: If the buffer is smaller than GIT_OID_HEXSZ+1, then the resulting oid c-string will be truncated to n-1 characters. If there are any input parameter errors (out == NULL, n == 0, oid == NULL), then a pointer to an empty string is returned, so that the return value can always be printed.

args.name: out
args.comment: oid structure the result is written into.

git_oid_cpy.description: Copy an oid from one structure to another.

args.name: len
args.comment: the number of hex chars to compare

git_oid_ncmp.argline: const git_oid *a, const git_oid *b, unsigned int len
git_oid_ncmp.description: Compare the first 'len' hexadecimal characters (packets of 4 bits) of two oid structures.

args.name: str
args.comment: input hex string of an object id.

return.comment: GIT_ENOTOID if str is not a valid hex string, GIT_SUCCESS in case of a match, GIT_ERROR otherwise.

git_oid_streq.description: Check if an oid equals an hex formatted object id.

args.name: min_length
args.comment: The minimal length for all identifiers, which will be used even if shorter OIDs would still be unique.

git_oid_shorten_new.comments:
The OID shortener is used to process a list of OIDs in text form and return the shortest length that would uniquely identify all of them.

E.g. look at the result of git log --abbrev.

return.comment: the minimal length to uniquely identify all OIDs added so far to the set; or an error code (<0) if an error occurs.

git_oid_shorten_add.description: Add a new OID to set of shortened OIDs and calculate the minimal length to uniquely identify all the OIDs in the set.
git_oid_shorten_add.comments:
The OID is expected to be a 40-char hexadecimal string. The OID is owned by the user and will not be modified or freed.

For performance reasons, there is a hard-limit of how many OIDs can be added to a single set (around ~22000, assuming a mostly randomized distribution), which should be enough for any kind of program, and keeps the algorithm fast and memory-efficient.

Attempting to add more than those OIDs will result in a GIT_ENOMEM error

git_reflog_read.description: Read the reflog for the given reference
git_reflog_read.comments: The reflog must be freed manually by using git_reflog_free().

args.name: oid_old
args.comment: the OID the reference was pointing to

git_reflog_write.argline: git_reference *ref, const git_oid *oid_old, const git_signature *committer, const char *msg
git_reflog_write.description: Write a new reflog for the given reference
git_reflog_write.comments:
If there is no reflog file for the given reference yet, it will be created.

oid_old may be NULL in case it's a new reference.

msg is optional and can be NULL.

args.name: new_name
args.comment: the new name of the reference

git_reflog_rename.description: Rename the reflog for the given reference

git_reflog_delete.description: Delete the reflog for the given reference

git_reflog_entrycount.description: Get the number of log entries in a reflog

return.comment: the entry; NULL if not found
the new oid at this time

args.name: repo
args.comment: the repository to look up the reference

args.name: name
args.comment: the long name for the reference (e.g. HEAD, ref/heads/master, refs/tags/v0.1.0, ...)

git_reference_lookup.description: Lookup a reference by its name in a repository.
git_reference_lookup.comments: The generated reference must be freed by the user.

args.name: ref_out
args.comment: Pointer to the newly created reference

args.name: repo
args.comment: Repository where that reference will live

git_reference_create_symbolic.argline: git_reference **ref_out, git_repository *repo, const char *name, const char *target, int force
git_reference_create_symbolic.comments:
The reference will be created in the repository and written to the disk.

The generated reference must be freed by the user.

If force is true and there already exists a reference with the same name, it will be overwritten.

args.name: ref_out
args.comment: Pointer to the newly created reference

args.name: repo
args.comment: Repository where that reference will live

args.name: id
args.comment: The object id pointed to by the reference.

git_reference_create_oid.argline: git_reference **ref_out, git_repository *repo, const char *name, const git_oid *id, int force
git_reference_create_oid.comments:
The reference will be created in the repository and written to the disk.

The generated reference must be freed by the user.

If force is true and there already exists a reference with the same name, it will be overwritten.

return.comment: a pointer to the oid if available, NULL otherwise

git_reference_oid.description: Get the OID pointed to by a reference.
git_reference_oid.comments: Only available if the reference is direct (i.e. not symbolic)

return.comment: a pointer to the name if available, NULL otherwise

git_reference_target.description: Get full name to the reference pointed by this reference
git_reference_target.comments: Only available if the reference is symbolic

return.comment: the full name for the ref

git_reference_name.description: Get the full name of a reference

git_reference_resolve.comments:
Thie method iteratively peels a symbolic reference until it resolves to a direct reference to an OID.

The peeled reference is returned in the resolved_ref argument, and must be freed manually once it's no longer needed.

If a direct reference is passed as an argument, a copy of that reference is returned. This copy must be manually freed too.

git_reference_owner.description: Get the repository where a reference resides

args.name: target
args.comment: The new target for the reference

git_reference_set_target.description: Set the symbolic target of a reference.
git_reference_set_target.comments:
The reference must be a symbolic reference, otherwise this method will fail.

The reference will be automatically updated in memory and on disk.

args.name: id
args.comment: The new target OID for the reference

git_reference_set_oid.description: Set the OID target of a reference.
git_reference_set_oid.comments:
The reference must be a direct reference, otherwise this method will fail.

The reference will be automatically updated in memory and on disk.

args.name: new_name
args.comment: The new name for the reference

git_reference_rename.comments:
This method works for both direct and symbolic references. The new name will be checked for validity and may be modified into a normalized form.

The given git_reference will be updated in place.

The reference will be immediately renamed in-memory and on disk.

If the force flag is not enabled, and there's already a reference with the given name, the renaming will fail.

IMPORTANT: The user needs to write a proper reflog entry if the reflog is enabled for the repository. We only rename the reflog if it exists.

git_reference_delete.comments:
This method works for both direct and symbolic references.

The reference will be immediately removed on disk and from memory. The given reference pointer will no longer be valid.

args.name: repo
args.comment: Repository where the loose refs will be packed

git_reference_packall.description: Pack all the loose references in the repository
git_reference_packall.comments:
This method will load into the cache all the loose references on the repository and update the packed-refs file with them.

Once the packed-refs file has been written properly, the loose references will be removed from disk.

args.name: array
args.comment: Pointer to a git_strarray structure where the reference names will be stored

args.name: repo
args.comment: Repository where to find the refs

args.name: list_flags
args.comment: Filtering flags for the reference listing.

git_reference_listall.description: Fill a list with all the references that can be found in a repository.
git_reference_listall.comments:
The listed references may be filtered by type, or using a bitwise OR of several types. Use the magic value GIT_REF_LISTALL to obtain all references, including packed ones.

The string array will be filled with the names of all references; these values are owned by the user and should be free'd manually when no longer needed, using git_strarray_free.

args.name: repo
args.comment: Repository where to find the refs

args.name: list_flags
args.comment: Filtering flags for the reference listing.

args.name: callback
args.comment: Function which will be called for every listed ref

args.name: payload
args.comment: Additional data to pass to the callback

git_reference_foreach.argline: git_repository *repo, unsigned int list_flags, int (*callback)(const char *, void *), void *payload
git_reference_foreach.description: Perform an operation on each reference in the repository
git_reference_foreach.comments:
The processed references may be filtered by type, or using a bitwise OR of several types. Use the magic value GIT_REF_LISTALL to obtain all references, including packed ones.

The callback function will be called for each of the references in the repository, and will receive the name of the reference and the payload value passed to this method.

return.comment: 0 in case it's not packed; 1 otherwise

git_reference_is_packed.description: Check if a reference has been loaded from a packfile

return.comment: GIT_SUCCESS on success, or an error code

git_reference_reload.comments:
Reference pointers may become outdated if the Git repository is accessed simultaneously by other clients whilt the library is open.

This method forces a reload of the reference from disk, to ensure that the provided information is still reliable.

If the reload fails (e.g. the reference no longer exists on disk, or has become corrupted), an error code will be returned and the reference pointer will be invalidated.

args.name: refname
args.comment: the name of the reference to check

return.comment: GIT_SUCCESS on successful match; GIT_ENOMACH on match failure or an error code on other failure

git_refspec_src_match.description: Match a refspec's source descriptor with a reference name

args.name: out
args.comment: where to store the target name

args.name: name
args.comment: the name of the reference to transform

git_refspec_transform.argline: char *out, size_t outlen, const git_refspec *spec, const char *name
git_refspec_transform.description: Transform a reference to its target following the refspec's rules

args.name: out
args.comment: pointer to the new remote object

git_remote_new.argline: git_remote **out, git_repository *repo, const char *url, const char *name
git_remote_new.comments: Create a remote with the default refspecs in memory. You can use this when you have a URL instead of a remote's name.

args.name: out
args.comment: pointer to the new remote object

git_remote_load.description: Get the information for a particular remote

return.comment: a pointer to the fetch refspec or NULL if it doesn't exist
a pointer to the push refspec or NULL if it doesn't exist

args.name: direction
args.comment: whether you want to receive or send data

git_remote_connect.comments: The transport is selected based on the URL. The direction argument is due to a limitation of the git protocol (over TCP or SSH) which starts up a specific binary which can only do the one or the other.

git_remote_ls.description: Get a list of refs at the remote
git_remote_ls.comments: The remote (or more exactly its transport) must be connected. The memory belongs to the remote.

args.name: filename
args.comment: where to store the temproray filename

git_remote_download.comments: Negotiate what objects should be downloaded and download the packfile with those objects. The packfile is downloaded with a temporary filename, as it's final name is not known yet. If there was no packfile needed (all the objects were available locally), filename will be NULL and the function will return success.

git_remote_connected.comments: Check whether the remote's underlying transport is connected to the remote host.

git_remote_disconnect.comments: Close the connection to the remote and free the underlying transport.

git_remote_free.description: Free the memory associated with a remote

git_remote_update_tips.description: Update the tips to the new state
git_remote_update_tips.comments: Make sure that you only call this once you've successfully indexed or expanded the packfile.

git_remote_valid_url.description: Return whether a string is a valid remote URL

args.name: repository
args.comment: pointer to the repo which will be opened

git_repository_open.comments:
The 'path' argument must point to either a git repository folder, or an existing work dir.

The method will automatically detect if 'path' is a normal or bare repository or fail is 'path' is neither.

args.name: repository_path
args.comment: The user allocated buffer which will contain the found path.

args.name: start_path
args.comment: The base path where the lookup starts.

args.name: across_fs
args.comment: If true, then the lookup will not stop when a filesystem device change is detected while exploring parent directories.

args.name: ceiling_dirs
args.comment: A GIT_PATH_LIST_SEPARATOR separated list of absolute symbolic link free paths. The lookup will stop when any of this paths is reached. Note that the lookup always performs on start_path no matter start_path appears in ceiling_dirs ceiling_dirs might be NULL (which is equivalent to an empty string)

git_repository_discover.argline:
char *repository_path,
		size_t size,
		const char *start_path,
		int across_fs,
		const char *ceiling_dirs
git_repository_discover.description: Look for a git repository and copy its path in the given buffer. The lookup start from base_path and walk across parent directories if nothing has been found. The lookup ends when the first repository is found, or when reaching a directory referenced in ceiling_dirs or when the filesystem changes (in case across_fs is true).
git_repository_discover.comments: The method will automatically detect if the repository is bare (if there is a repository).

args.name: repo
args.comment: repository handle to close. If NULL nothing occurs.

git_repository_free.comments: Note that after a repository is free'd, all the objects it has spawned will still exist until they are manually closed by the user with git_object_free, but accessing any of the attributes of an object without a backing repository will result in undefined behavior

args.name: repo_out
args.comment: pointer to the repo which will be created or reinitialized

args.name: is_bare
args.comment: if true, a Git repository without a working directory is created at the pointed path. If false, provided path will be considered as the working directory into which the .git directory will be created.

git_repository_init.description: Creates a new Git repository in the given folder.

args.name: head_out
args.comment: pointer to the reference which will be retrieved

git_repository_head.description: Retrieve and resolve the reference pointed at by HEAD.

return.comment: 1 if HEAD is detached, 0 if i'ts not; error code if there was an error.

git_repository_head_detached.description: Check if a repository's HEAD is detached
git_repository_head_detached.comments: A repository's HEAD is detached when it points directly to a commit instead of a branch.

return.comment: 1 if the current branch is an orphan, 0 if it's not; error code if therewas an error

git_repository_head_orphan.description: Check if the current branch is an orphan
git_repository_head_orphan.comments: An orphan branch is one named from HEAD but which doesn't exist in the refs namespace, because it doesn't have any commit to point to.

return.comment: 1 if the repository is empty, 0 if it isn't, error code if the repository is corrupted

git_repository_is_empty.comments: An empty repository has just been initialized and contains no commits.

git_repository_path.comments: This is the path of the .git folder for normal repositories, or of the repository itself for bare repositories.

return.comment: the path to the working dir, if it exists

git_repository_workdir.description: Get the path of the working directory for this repository
git_repository_workdir.comments: If the repository is bare, this function will always return NULL.

args.name: workdir
args.comment: The path to a working directory

git_repository_set_workdir.description: Set the path to the working directory for this repository
git_repository_set_workdir.comments:
The working directory doesn't need to be the same one that contains the .git folder for this repository.

If this repository is bare, setting its working directory will turn it into a normal repository, capable of performing all the common workdir operations (checkout, status, index manipulation, etc).

return.comment: 1 if the repository is bare, 0 otherwise.

args.name: out
args.comment: Pointer to store the loaded config file

git_repository_config.description: Get the configuration file for this repository.
git_repository_config.comments:
If a configuration file has not been set, the default config set for the repository will be returned, including global and system configurations (if they are available).

The configuration file must be freed once it's no longer being used by the user.

git_repository_set_config.description: Set the configuration file for this repository
git_repository_set_config.comments:
This configuration file will be used for all configuration queries involving this repository.

The repository will keep a reference to the config file; the user must still free the config after setting it to the repository, or it will leak.

args.name: out
args.comment: Pointer to store the loaded ODB

git_repository_odb.description: Get the Object Database for this repository.
git_repository_odb.comments:
If a custom ODB has not been set, the default database for the repository will be returned (the one located in .git/objects).

The ODB must be freed once it's no longer being used by the user.

git_repository_set_odb.description: Set the Object Database for this repository
git_repository_set_odb.comments:
The ODB will be used for all object-related operations involving this repository.

The repository will keep a reference to the ODB; the user must still free the ODB object after setting it to the repository, or it will leak.

args.name: out
args.comment: Pointer to store the loaded index

git_repository_index.description: Get the Index file for this repository.
git_repository_index.comments:
If a custom index has not been set, the default index for the repository will be returned (the one located in .git/index).

The index must be freed once it's no longer being used by the user.

git_repository_set_index.description: Set the index file for this repository
git_repository_set_index.comments:
This index will be used for all index-related operations involving this repository.

The repository will keep a reference to the index file; the user must still free the index after setting it to the repository, or it will leak.

args.name: walker
args.comment: pointer to the new revision walker

git_revwalk_new.description: Allocate a new revision walker to iterate through a repo.
git_revwalk_new.comments:
This revision walker uses a custom memory pool and an internal commit cache, so it is relatively expensive to allocate.

For maximum performance, this revision walker should be reused for different walks.

This revision walker is not thread safe: it may only be used to walk a repository on a single thread; however, it is possible to have several revision walkers in several different threads walking the same repository.

git_revwalk_reset.comments:
This will clear all the pushed and hidden commits, and leave the walker in a blank state (just like at creation) ready to receive new commit pushes and start a new walk.

The revision walk is automatically reset when a walk is over.

args.name: walk
args.comment: the walker being used for the traversal.

args.name: oid
args.comment: the oid of the commit to start from.

git_revwalk_push.description: Mark a commit to start traversal from.
git_revwalk_push.comments:
The given OID must belong to a commit on the walked repository.

The given commit will be used as one of the roots when starting the revision walk. At least one commit must be pushed the repository before a walk can be started.

args.name: walk
args.comment: the walker being used for the traversal.

args.name: oid
args.comment: the oid of commit that will be ignored during the traversal

git_revwalk_hide.description: Mark a commit (and its ancestors) uninteresting for the output.
git_revwalk_hide.comments:
The given OID must belong to a commit on the walked repository.

The resolved commit and all its parents will be hidden from the output on the revision walk.

args.name: oid
args.comment: Pointer where to store the oid of the next commit

args.name: walk
args.comment: the walker to pop the commit from.

return.comment: GIT_SUCCESS if the next commit was found; GIT_EREVWALKOVER if there are no commits left to iterate

git_revwalk_next.description: Get the next commit from the revision walk.
git_revwalk_next.comments:
The initial call to this method is not blocking when iterating through a repo with a time-sorting mode.

Iterating with Topological or inverted modes makes the initial call blocking to preprocess the commit list, but this block should be mostly unnoticeable on most repositories (topological preprocessing times at 0.3s on the git.git repo).

The revision walker is reset when the walk is over.

args.name: walk
args.comment: the walker being used for the traversal.

git_revwalk_sorting.description: Change the sorting mode when iterating through the repository's contents.
git_revwalk_sorting.comments: Changing the sorting mode resets the walker.

args.name: walk
args.comment: traversal handle to close. If NULL nothing occurs.

git_revwalk_repository.description: Return the repository on which this walker is operating.

args.name: sig_out
args.comment: new signature, in case of error NULL

args.name: offset
args.comment: timezone offset in minutes for the time

git_signature_new.argline: git_signature **sig_out, const char *name, const char *email, git_time_t time, int offset
git_signature_new.description: Create a new action signature. The signature must be freed manually or using git_signature_free

args.name: sig_out
args.comment: new signature, in case of error NULL

git_signature_now.description: Create a new action signature with a timestamp of 'now'. The signature must be freed manually or using git_signature_free

return.comment: a copy of sig, NULL on out of memory

git_signature_dup.description: Create a copy of an existing signature.

args.name: callback
args.comment: the function to call on each file

git_status_foreach.argline: git_repository *repo, int (*callback)(const char *, unsigned int, void *), void *payload

return.comment: GIT_SUCCESS or the return value of the callback which did not return GIT_SUCCESS

git_status_foreach.description: Gather file statuses and run a callback for each one.
git_status_foreach.comments: The callback is passed the path of the file, the status and the data pointer passed to this function. If the callback returns something other than GIT_SUCCESS, this function will return that value.

args.name: path
args.comment: the file to retrieve status for, rooted at the repo's workdir

return.comment: GIT_EINVALIDPATH when `path` points at a folder, GIT_ENOTFOUND when the file doesn't exist in any of HEAD, the index or the worktree, GIT_SUCCESS otherwise

git_status_file.description: Get file status for a single file

args.name: path
args.comment: the file to check ignores for, rooted at the repo's workdir

args.name: ignored
args.comment: boolean returning 0 if the file is not ignored, 1 if it is

return.comment: GIT_SUCCESS if the ignore rules could be processed for the file (regardless of whether it exists or not), or an error < 0 if they could not.

git_status_should_ignore.description: Test if the ignore rules apply to a given file.
git_status_should_ignore.comments: This function simply checks the ignore rules to see if they would apply to the given file. Unlike git_status_file(), this indicates if the file would be ignored regardless of whether the file is already in the index or in the repository.

args.name: tag
args.comment: pointer to the looked up tag

args.name: repo
args.comment: the repo to use when locating the tag.

args.name: id
args.comment: identity of the tag to locate.

git_tag_lookup.description: Lookup a tag object from the repository.

args.name: tag
args.comment: pointer to the looked up tag

args.name: repo
args.comment: the repo to use when locating the tag.

args.name: id
args.comment: identity of the tag to locate.

args.name: len
args.comment: the length of the short identifier

git_tag_lookup_prefix.argline: git_tag **tag, git_repository *repo, const git_oid *id, unsigned int len
git_tag_lookup_prefix.description: Lookup a tag object from the repository, given a prefix of its identifier (short id).

git_tag_free.comments:
This is a wrapper around git_object_free()

IMPORTANT: It is necessary to call this method when you stop using a tag. Failure to do so will cause a memory leak.

args.name: target
args.comment: pointer where to store the target

git_tag_target.description: Get the tagged object of a tag
git_tag_target.comments: This method performs a repository lookup for the given object and returns it

git_tag_target_oid.description: Get the OID of the tagged object of a tag

git_tag_type.description: Get the type of a tag's tagged object

args.name: oid
args.comment: Pointer where to store the OID of the newly created tag. If the tag already exists, this parameter will be the oid of the existing tag, and the function will return a GIT_EEXISTS error code.

args.name: repo
args.comment: Repository where to store the tag

args.name: tag_name
args.comment: Name for the tag; this name is validated for consistency. It should also not conflict with an already existing tag name

args.name: target
args.comment: Object to which this tag points. This object must belong to the given `repo`.

args.name: tagger
args.comment: Signature of the tagger for this tag, and of the tagging time

return.comment: GIT_SUCCESS or an error code A tag object is written to the ODB, and a proper reference is written in the /refs/tags folder, pointing to it

git_tag_create.description: Create a new tag in the repository from an object
git_tag_create.comments: A new reference will also be created pointing to this tag object. If force is true and a reference already exists with the given name, it'll be replaced.

args.name: oid
args.comment: Pointer where to store the OID of the newly created tag

args.name: repo
args.comment: Repository where to store the tag

git_tag_create_frombuffer.argline:
git_oid *oid,
		git_repository *repo,
		const char *buffer,
		int force
git_tag_create_frombuffer.description: Create a new tag in the repository from a buffer

args.name: oid
args.comment: Pointer where to store the OID of the provided target object. If the tag already exists, this parameter will be filled with the oid of the existing pointed object and the function will return a GIT_EEXISTS error code.

args.name: repo
args.comment: Repository where to store the lightweight tag

args.name: tag_name
args.comment: Name for the tag; this name is validated for consistency. It should also not conflict with an already existing tag name

args.name: target
args.comment: Object to which this tag points. This object must belong to the given `repo`.

return.comment: GIT_SUCCESS or an error code A proper reference is written in the /refs/tags folder, pointing to the provided target object

git_tag_create_lightweight.description: Create a new lightweight tag pointing at a target object
git_tag_create_lightweight.comments: A new direct reference will be created pointing to this target object. If force is true and a reference already exists with the given name, it'll be replaced.

args.name: tag_name
args.comment: Name of the tag to be deleted; this name is validated for consistency.

args.name: tag_names
args.comment: Pointer to a git_strarray structure where the tag names will be stored

args.name: repo
args.comment: Repository where to find the tags

git_tag_list.description: Fill a list with all the tags in the Repository
git_tag_list.comments: The string array will be filled with the names of the matching tags; these values are owned by the user and should be free'd manually when no longer needed, using git_strarray_free.

args.name: tag_names
args.comment: Pointer to a git_strarray structure where the tag names will be stored

args.name: repo
args.comment: Repository where to find the tags

git_tag_list_match.description: Fill a list with all the tags in the Repository which name match a defined pattern
git_tag_list_match.comments:
If an empty pattern is provided, all the tags will be returned.

The string array will be filled with the names of the matching tags; these values are owned by the user and should be free'd manually when no longer needed, using git_strarray_free.

git_threads_init.comments:
If libgit2 has been built with GIT_THREADS on, this function must be called once before any other library functions.

If libgit2 has been built without GIT_THREADS support, this function is a no-op.

git_threads_shutdown.comments:
If libgit2 has been built with GIT_THREADS on, this function must be called before shutting down the library.

If libgit2 has been built without GIT_THREADS support, this function is a no-op.

args.name: tree
args.comment: pointer to the looked up tree

args.name: repo
args.comment: the repo to use when locating the tree.

args.name: id
args.comment: identity of the tree to locate.

git_tree_lookup.description: Lookup a tree object from the repository.

args.name: tree
args.comment: pointer to the looked up tree

args.name: repo
args.comment: the repo to use when locating the tree.

args.name: id
args.comment: identity of the tree to locate.

args.name: len
args.comment: the length of the short identifier

git_tree_lookup_prefix.argline: git_tree **tree, git_repository *repo, const git_oid *id, unsigned int len
git_tree_lookup_prefix.description: Lookup a tree object from the repository, given a prefix of its identifier (short id).

git_tree_free.comments:
This is a wrapper around git_object_free()

IMPORTANT: It is necessary to call this method when you stop using a tree. Failure to do so will cause a memory leak.

return.comment: the number of entries in the tree

git_tree_entrycount.description: Get the number of entries listed in a tree

args.name: filename
args.comment: the filename of the desired entry

return.comment: the tree entry; NULL if not found

git_tree_entry_byname.description: Lookup a tree entry by its filename

args.name: idx
args.comment: the position in the entry list

return.comment: the tree entry; NULL if not found

git_tree_entry_byindex.description: Lookup a tree entry by its position in the tree

git_tree_entry_attributes.description: Get the UNIX file attributes of a tree entry

git_tree_entry_name.description: Get the filename of a tree entry

git_tree_entry_id.description: Get the id of the object pointed by the entry

return.comment: the type of the pointed object

git_tree_entry_type.description: Get the type of the object pointed by the entry

args.name: repo
args.comment: repository where to lookup the pointed object

git_tree_entry_2object.description: Convert a tree entry to the git_object it points too.

args.name: oid
args.comment: Pointer where to store the written tree

git_tree_create_fromindex.description: Write a tree to the ODB from the index file
git_tree_create_fromindex.comments:
This method will scan the index and write a representation of its current state back to disk; it recursively creates tree objects for each of the subtrees stored in the index, but only returns the OID of the root tree. This is the OID that can be used e.g. to create a commit.

The index instance cannot be bare, and needs to be associated to an existing repository.

args.name: builder_p
args.comment: Pointer where to store the tree builder

args.name: source
args.comment: Source tree to initialize the builder (optional)

git_treebuilder_create.comments:
The tree builder can be used to create or modify trees in memory and write them as tree objects to the database.

If the source parameter is not NULL, the tree builder will be initialized with the entries of the given tree.

If the source parameter is NULL, the tree builder will have no entries and will have to be filled manually.

git_treebuilder_clear.description: Clear all the entires in the builder

git_treebuilder_free.comments: This will clear all the entries and free to builder. Failing to free the builder after you're done using it will result in a memory leak

return.comment: pointer to the entry; NULL if not found

git_treebuilder_get.description: Get an entry from the builder from its filename
git_treebuilder_get.comments: The returned entry is owned by the builder and should not be freed manually.

git_treebuilder_insert.argline: git_tree_entry **entry_out, git_treebuilder *bld, const char *filename, const git_oid *id, unsigned int attributes
git_treebuilder_insert.description: Add or update an entry to the builder
git_treebuilder_insert.comments:
Insert a new entry for filename in the builder with the given attributes.

if an entry named filename already exists, its attributes will be updated with the given ones.

The optional pointer entry_out can be used to retrieve a pointer to the newly created/updated entry.

args.name: filename
args.comment: Filename of the entry to remove

git_treebuilder_remove.description: Remove an entry from the builder by its filename

git_treebuilder_filter.comments: The filter callback will be called for each entry in the tree with a pointer to the entry and the provided payload: if the callback returns 1, the entry will be filtered (removed from the builder).

args.name: oid
args.comment: Pointer where to store the written OID

args.name: repo
args.comment: Repository where to store the object

git_treebuilder_write.description: Write the contents of the tree builder as a tree object
git_treebuilder_write.comments: The tree builder will be written to the given repo, and it's identifying SHA1 hash will be stored in the oid pointer.

args.name: subtree
args.comment: Pointer where to store the subtree

args.name: root
args.comment: A previously loaded tree which will be the root of the relative path

return.comment: GIT_SUCCESS on success; GIT_ENOTFOUND if the path does not lead to a subtree, GIT_EINVALIDPATH or an error code

git_tree_get_subtree.description: Retrieve a subtree contained in a tree, given its relative path.
git_tree_get_subtree.comments: The returned tree is owned by the repository and should be closed with the git_object_free method.

args.name: callback
args.comment: Function to call on each tree entry

args.name: payload
args.comment: Opaque pointer to be passed on each callback

git_tree_walk.argline: git_tree *tree, git_treewalk_cb callback, int mode, void *payload
git_tree_walk.description: Traverse the entries in a tree and its subtrees in post or pre order
git_tree_walk.comments:
The entries will be traversed in the specified order, children subtrees will be automatically loaded as required, and the callback will be called once per entry with the current (relative) root for the entry and the entry data itself.

If the callback returns a negative value, the passed entry will be skiped on the traversal.

args.name: data
args.comment: data to give to the callback

git_tree_diff.comments: Compare two trees. For each difference in the trees, the callback will be called with a git_tree_diff_data filled with the relevant information.

gitwin_set_codepage.description: Set the active codepage for Windows syscalls
gitwin_set_codepage.comments:
All syscalls performed by the library will assume this codepage when converting paths and strings to use by the Windows kernel.

The default value of UTF-8 will work automatically with most Git repositories created on Unix systems.

This settings needs only be changed when working with repositories that contain paths in specific, non-UTF codepages.

A full list of all available codepage identifiers may be found at:

http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/dd317756(v=vs.85).aspx

gitwin_get_codepage.description: Return the active codepage for Windows syscalls

gitwin_set_utf8.description: Set the active Windows codepage to UTF-8 (this is the default value)

return.comment: maximum length of the compressed data.

deflateBound.description: deflateBound returns an upper bound on the compressed size.
deflateBound.comments: This is a stub function used when zlib does not supply the deflateBound() implementation itself.

GIT_EXTERN(type).comments: Declare a public function exported for application use.

GIT_FORMAT_PRINTF(a,b).comments: Declare a function's takes printf style arguments.

GIT_PATH_LIST_SEPARATOR.comments: The separator used in path list strings (ie like in the PATH environment variable). A semi-colon ";" is used on Windows, and a colon ":" for all other systems.

GIT_PATH_MAX.comments: The maximum length of a git valid git path.

GIT_OID_HEXSZ.comments: Size (in bytes) of a hex formatted oid

GIT_OID_MINPREFIXLEN.comments: Minimum length (in number of hex characters, i.e. packets of 4 bits) of an oid prefix

GIT_SORT_NONE.comments: Sort the repository contents in no particular ordering; this sorting is arbitrary, implementation-specific and subject to change at any time. This is the default sorting for new walkers.

GIT_SORT_TOPOLOGICAL.comments: Sort the repository contents in topological order (parents before children); this sorting mode can be combined with time sorting.

GIT_SORT_TIME.comments: Sort the repository contents by commit time; this sorting mode can be combined with topological sorting.

GIT_SORT_REVERSE.comments: Iterate through the repository contents in reverse order; this sorting mode can be combined with any of the above.

types.comments: Memory representation of a set of config files

git_oid oid[3]

Time used in a git index entry

unsigned int total
unsigned int processed
